questions.section: When to Hire Your First Data Person
questions.question: What are signals that you're ready to hire your first data person?

options.text: Partners are spending significant time on manual data tasks that could be automated
You have a specific technical initiative that needs leadership
The fund has conviction that data and technology will be core to differentiation
All of the above

questions.explanation: Signals that you're ready: partners are spending significant time on manual data tasks that could be automated, you have a specific technical initiative that needs leadership (not just a vague 'we should be more data-driven'), the fund has conviction that data and technology will be core to differentiation (not just operational efficiency), and you have budget for the hire and the tools, infrastructure, and data they'll need.

questions.section: When to Hire Your First Data Person
questions.question: What are signals that you're NOT ready to hire?

options.text: 'Data-driven' is a buzzword in your marketing, not a real strategy
You expect one person to solve all technical problems while you figure out what you actually need
There's no budget for data subscriptions, cloud infrastructure, or tooling beyond salary
All of the above

questions.explanation: Signals that you're not ready: 'Data-driven' is a buzzword in your marketing, not a real strategy. You expect one person to solve all technical problems while you figure out what you actually need. There's no budget for data subscriptions, cloud infrastructure, or tooling beyond salary. Partners aren't willing to invest time in defining problems and giving feedback. Many successful funds operate without dedicated technical staff using off-the-shelf tools.

questions.section: What to Look for in Your First Hire
questions.question: What is the ideal technical profile for your first hire?

options.text: Broad software engineering skills, data engineering depth, VC domain knowledge
Only VC domain knowledge
Only technical skills
Only data engineering skills

questions.explanation: The ideal technical profile: broad software engineering skills, data engineering depth (pipelines, databases, integrations), and VC domain knowledge. Technical skills are learnable. Product sense in a specialized domain like VC is harder to acquire. How much you weight vision-selling versus hands-on execution depends on fund size and team structure.

questions.section: What to Look for in Your First Hire
questions.question: What is the biggest mistake funds make when hiring their first technical person?

options.text: Hiring too senior
Hiring too junior - someone early in their career often struggles without external structure
Hiring someone with too much experience
Hiring someone from a tech company

questions.explanation: Hiring too junior is the biggest mistake funds make. Someone early in their career, even if technically capable, often struggles without external structure. Look for someone who has shipped projects end-to-end with minimal supervision. The first tech hire should be able to sell the vision of what's possible with data & tech internally and generate excitement among partners. They need to be self-motivated to identify opportunities and pitch their own projects.

questions.section: What to Look for in Your First Hire
questions.question: According to Ties Boukema at Dawn Capital, what should the first tech hire be able to do?

options.text: Sell the vision of what's possible with data & tech internally and generate excitement
Be self-motivated to identify opportunities where data, tech & AI can add value and pitch their own projects
Be proactive problem-identifiers who can independently scope and drive their own work
All of the above

questions.explanation: The first tech hire should be able to sell the vision of what's possible with data & tech internally and generate excitement among partners. They need to be self-motivated to identify opportunities where data, tech & AI can add value and pitch their own projects. Great tech hires need to be proactive problem-identifiers who can independently scope and drive their own work rather than wait for assignments. This is different from typical banking or consulting analysts who are accustomed to working on urgent, well-scoped deliverables.

questions.question: When should you hire a second person?

options.text: Immediately after hiring the first person
When you have clear, separable workstreams, the first hire is consistently underwater, or you've identified a big swing that requires dedicated focus
After one year regardless of workload
When the first hire asks for help

questions.explanation: Don't hire a second person until the first hire has identified clear workstreams to divide. When to hire a second person: you have clear, separable workstreams (e.g., data infrastructure vs. internal tools vs. ML/AI initiatives), the first hire is consistently underwater despite good prioritization, or you've identified a big swing that requires dedicated focus and the first hire can't abandon other responsibilities. The first hire's job isn't just building tools - it's discovering what the fund actually needs.

questions.question: When should you hire specialists (ML engineers, data engineers, etc.)?

options.text: Immediately to have a complete team
Only hire specialists when there's enough work to keep them occupied long-term
Hire them before the generalist
Hire them for short-term projects

questions.explanation: Only hire specialists when there's enough work to keep them occupied long-term. If you want to take a big swing on AI/ML, use the first hire to scope it and build the data infrastructure to support it, then hire someone dedicated to that initiative. For niche specialties with uncertain long-term demand, use consultants for the initial build. Larger funds often do this: bring in external help to ship something, then decide whether the workstream justifies a full-time hire. The pattern is: generalist first to figure out what matters, then specialists for sustained investment in specific areas.

questions.question: What is the compensation structure typically like for VC fund technical roles?

options.text: Base salaries typically in line with tech companies, carry is rare but becoming more common, equity is non-existent
Much lower than tech companies
Equity like startups
Only carry, no base salary

questions.explanation: On compensation: base salaries are typically in line with tech companies. Carried interest (carry) is still rare for technical hires but becoming more common, especially at senior levels. Equity is non-existent (VC funds don't have equity like startups do). The value proposition is: interesting problems, high autonomy, direct impact, exposure to the startup ecosystem. VC fund technical roles sit awkwardly in the market - you're not a big tech company with standard levels, you're not a startup with equity upside.

questions.question: What are red flags to watch out for in candidates? (Select all that apply)

options.text: No evidence of independent ownership - every example involves working within a well-defined scope
Dismissive of 'boring' work like data pipelines and integrations
Can't explain technical concepts simply to non-technical people
Has shipped projects end-to-end with minimal supervision

questions.explanation: Watch out for these warning signs: No evidence of independent ownership - ask about projects they drove end-to-end. If every example involves working within a well-defined scope set by someone else, they'll struggle in a VC environment. Dismissive of 'boring' work - data pipelines, integrations, and internal tools aren't glamorous. If a candidate only wants to work on interesting technical problems, they won't do the unglamorous work that actually matters. Can't explain technical concepts simply - they'll be working with non-technical people every day. If they can't translate technical trade-offs into business terms, they'll struggle to get buy-in for projects.

questions.question: What is the bottom line for hiring your first data person?

options.text: Your first hire needs broad software skills with depth in data engineering and VC domain knowledge
They should be able to sell the vision and deliver on it
Avoid hiring too junior
All of the above

questions.explanation: Your first hire needs broad software skills with depth in data engineering and VC domain knowledge. They should be able to sell the vision and deliver on it. Avoid hiring too junior. Let your first hire identify what actually matters before expanding the team. The first technical hire at a VC fund is a unique role: part engineer, part product manager, part internal consultant. Getting it right means finding someone who can operate independently in an ambiguous environment while delivering real value.
